div1.p: THE BASSET-Table. A COMEDY. As it is Acted at the Theatre-Royal in Drury-Lane, by Her Majesty's Servants.
By the Author of the Gamester.
LONDON: Printed for William Turner at the Angel at Lincolns-Inn-Back-Gate; and Sold by J. Nutt near Stationers-Hall, 1706. Price 1s. 6d.

div1.head: To the Right Honourable ARTHUR Lord ALTHAM, BARON of ALTHAM, In the Kingdom of IRELAND.
div1.p:
POetry, in its first Institution, was principally design'd to Correct, and rectify Manners. Thence it was that the Roman and Athenian Stages were accounted Schools of Divinity and Morality; where the Tragick Writers of those Days inspired their Audiences with Noble and Heroick Sentiments, and the Comick laugh'd and diverted them out of their Vices; and by rediculing Folly, Intemperence, and Debauchery,
gave them an Indignation for those Irregularities, and made them pursue the opposite Virtues.

This caus'd the Dramatic Poets, in ancient Times, not only to be reverenc'd by the lower sort of People, but highly Esteem'd and Courted by Persons of the first Rank; and tho' the Writers of latter Ages, have, in a greater Measure, not to say in a scandelous Manner, deviated from the Foot-steps, and Examples of their Predecessors; yet have they found Protection and Favour with those, who have been so Generous as to ascribe the Faults of the Poets to the Degeneracy of the Age wherein they liv'd.

This consideration, my Lord, has imbolden'd me to this Address, for tho' on the one Hand I am sensible, that the following Piece does little Merit your Lordship's Patronage; yet your innate Goodness and Generosity give me hopes, that your Lordship will Pardon this Intrusion, in
which I have the Examples of all those that wrote before me to bear me out. I heartily wish this Play were more worthy of your Lordship's Acceptance: Yet so much, I hope, will be forgiven to the fondness of a Mother for her Production; if, I say, in its Favour, that through the whole Piece, I have had a tender regard to good Manners, and by the main Drift of it, endeavour'd to Redicule and Correct one of the most reigning Vices of the Age. I might say, as many of my Brethren have done upon slighter Grounds, that this Play has had the good Fortune to Please and Divert the Nicest, and Politest Part of the Town; but I should set little Stress on their Applause, had I not some reason to depend upon your Lordship's Approbation, whose Judgement, Penetration and Discernment, are alone sufficient to do full Justice to a performance of this Kind.

And now, my Lord, if I follow'd the beaten Road of Dedicators, it would naturally Engage me in a Panegirick, upon your Lordship's Personal Virtues, and those of your Noble and Pious Family; but I shall purposely decline a Talk to which I freely own my Ability is Unequal, and which, tho' manag'd by a Masterly Pen, would make your Modesty suffer. Therefore I shall conclude, with begging your Lordship's leave to Subscribe my self, with all imaginable Respect and Sincerity.

closer.signed: Your Lordship's most Obedient, and most Devoted Humble Servant,

div1.head: PROLOGUE
div1.l: IN all the Faces that to Plays Resort,
Whether of Country, City, Mob or Court;
I've always found that none such hopes Inspire,
As you—dear Brethren of the Upper Tire.
Poets in Prologues, may both Preach and Rail,
Yet all their Wisdom, nothing will avail,
Who writes not up to you, 'tis ten to one will fail.
Your thundring plaudit 'tis that deals out Fame,
You make Plays run, tho' of themselves but Lame:
How often have we known your Noise Commanding,
Impose on your Inferior Masters Understanding;
Therefore, Dear Brethren, (since I am one of you)
Whether adorn'd in Grey, Green, Brown or Blue,
This day stand all by me, as I will fall by you,
And now to let—
The poor Pit see how Pinky's Voice Commands,
Silence—Now rattle all your Sticks, and clap your grimy Hands▪
I greet your Love—and let the vainest Author show,
Half this Command on clearer Hands below,
Nay, more to prove your Interest, let this Play live by you.
So may you share good Claret with your Masters,
Still free in your Amours from their Disasters;
Free from poor House-keeping, where Peck is under Locks▪
Free from Cold Kitchings, and no Christmas Box:
So may no long Debates i'th' House of Commons,
Make you in the Lobby Starve, when hungar Summons:
But may your plentious Vails come flowing in,
Give you a lucky hit, and make you Gentlemen;
And thus preferr'd, ne'er fear the World's Reproaches,
But shake your Elbows with my Lord, and keep your Coaches:

div1.head: EPILOGUE
div1.l: THis goodly Fabrick to a gazing Tarr,
Seems Fore and Aft, a Three Deckt-man os War.
Abaft, the Hold's the Pit, from thence look up,
Aloft! that Swabber's Nest, that's the Main-Top.
Side-boxes mann'd with Beau, and modish Rake,
Are like the Fore-castle, and Quarter-Deck.
Those dark disguised, advent'rous, black-nos'd few,
May pass for Gunners, or a Fire-ship's Crew.
Some come like Privateers a Prize to seize,
And catch the French within the Narrow Seas.
The Orange-Ladies, Virgins of Renown,
Are Powder-Monkies running up and down.
We've here our Calms, our Storms, and prosp'rous Gales,
And shift our Scenes as Seamen shift their Sails.
The Ship's well mann'd, and not ill Woman'd neither,
So Ballast'd and Stow'd, my Lads, she'll bear the Weather.
But greater Dangers ventring Players alarm,
This Night's Engagement's worse than any Storm.
The Poet's Captain, but half dead with fright,
She leaves her Officers to maintain the Fight;
Yon'd middle Teer with Eighteen Pounders mauls us,
That Upper-Deck with Great and Small-Shot gauls us.
But from this Lower-Teer most Harm befals,
There's no opposing their prevailing Balls.
As either Foe or Friend their Chain-shot flies,
We sink or swim, we Conquer, Fall or Rise.
To fit and rig our Ships much Pains we take;
Grant we may now a Saving-Voyage make.
Here we're Embark'd, and as you Smile or Frown,
You are our Stars, by You we Live or Drown.

set.p: Scene. Lady Reveller's Lodgings in Covent-Garden; the Time; Four of the Clock in the Morning.

div1.head: ACT I.
div1.stage: A large Hall, a Porter with a Staff, several Chairs Waiting, and Footmen a-sleep, with Torches and Flambeauxs standing about the Room.

sp.speaker: Footman
sp.p: CErtainly they'l Play all Night, this is a cursed Life.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: How long have you liv'd with your Lady?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: A Month, too long by thirty Days, if this be her way of living; I shall be dead before the Year's out; she Games all Night, and Sleeps all Day.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: As long as you sleep, what's Matter?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: But I do not, for while she sleeps, I'm Employ'd in Howdee's, from one end of the Town to the other.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: But you rest while she's Gaming; What would you do, if you led my Life? This is my Lady's constant Practice

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Your Lady keeps a Basset Table, much good may do you with your Service—Hark, they are broke up. [within.] ha, hy, my Lady Gamewel's Chair ready there—Mr. Sonica's Servant (The Footmen wake in a hurry.

sp.speaker: 1st. Foot.
sp.p: Where the Devil is my Flambeaux?

sp.speaker: 2d. Foot.
sp.p: So-hey—Robin, get the Chair ready, my Lady's coming; stay, stay, let me light my Flambeaux.

sp.speaker: 3d. Foot.
sp.p: [waking] Hey, hoa, what han't they done Play yet?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: They are now coming down, but your Lady is gone half an hour ago.

sp.speaker: 3d. Foot.
sp.p: The Devil she is, why did not you call me?

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: I did not see you.

sp.speaker: 3d. Foot.
sp.p: Was you Blind?—She has lost her Money, that's certain—She never flinches upo naW inning-Hand—her Plate and Jewels Walks to Morrow to replenish her Pocket—a Pox of Gaming, I say.
[Within.] Mr. Looseall's Man—

sp.speaker: 4th Foot.
sp.p: Here—So-ho, who has stole my Flambeaux?
[Within.] My Lady Umbray's Coach there.—

sp.speaker: 5th Foot.
sp.p: Hey! Will, pull up there

div1.stage: Enter Lady Reveller and Alpiew, her Woman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Lady Raffle is horridly out of humour at her ill Fortune, she lost 300 l.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: She has generally ill luck, yet her Inclination for Play is as strong as ever.—Did your Ladyship win, or lose, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I won about 50 l.—prethee what shall we do, Alpiew? 'Tis a fine Morning, 'tis pity to go to Bed.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: What does your Ladiship think of a Walk in the Park?—The Park is pleasant in a Morning, the Air is so very sweet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I don't think so; the sweetness of the Park is at Eleven, when the Beau Monde makes their Tower there, 'tis an unpolish'd Curiosity to walk when only Birds can see one.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Bless me, Madam! Your Uncle—now for a Sermon of two Hours.

div1.stage: Enter Sir Richard Plainman, in a Night-Gown as from Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: So Niece! I find you're resolv'd to keep on your course of Life; I must be wak'd at Four with Coach, Coach, Chair, Chair; give over for shame, and Marry, Marry, Niece.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Now would I forfeit the Heart of my next Admirer, to know the cause of this Reproach. Pray, Uncle, explain'd your self; for I protest I can't guess what Crime I have unhappily committed to merit this advice.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: How can you look me in the Face, and ask me that Question? Can you that keep a Basset-Table, a publick Gaming-House, be insensible of the shame on't? I have often told you how much the vast concurse of People, which Day and Night make my House their Rendevouze, incommode my Health; your Apartment is a Parade for Men of all Ranks, from the Duke to the Fidler, and your Vanity thinks they all pay Devoir to your Beauty—but you mistake, every one has his several end in Meeting here, from the Lord to the Sharper, and each their seperate Interest to Admire—some Fools there may be, for there's seldom a crowd without.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Malice—some Fools? I can't bear it.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis very affronting, truly Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay, is it not Alpiew?—Yet, now I think on't, 'tis the defect of Age to rail at the Pleasure's of Youth, therefore I shall not disorder my Face with a frown about it. Ha, ha, I hope, Uncle, you'l take peculiar care of my Cousin Valeria, in disposing of her according to the Breeding you have given her.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: The Breeding I have given her! I would not have her have your Breeding, Mistress, for all the Wealth of England's Bank; no, I bread my Girl in the Country, a stranger to the Vices of this Town, and am resolv'd to Marry her to a Man of Honour, Probity and Courage.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What the Sea Captain, Uncle? Faugh, I hate the smell of Pitch and Tarr; one that can Entertain one with nothing but Fire and Smoak, Larboard and Starboard, and t'other Bowl of Punch, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: And for every fault that she commits he'll condemn her to the Bilboes, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I fancy my Cousin's Philosophy, and the Captain's Couragious Bluster, will make Angelick Harmony.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, sweeter Harmony than your Sept & Leva Fops, Rakes and Gamesters; give me the Man that serves my Country, that preserves both my Estate and Life—Oh, the glorious Name of Soldier; if I were Young, I'd go my self in Person, but as it is—

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: You'll send your Daughter—

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Yes, Minx, and a good Dowry with her, as a reward for Virtue like the Captains.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: But suppose, Sir, Mrs. Valeria should not like him?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I'll suppose no such thing, Mistress, she shall like him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, there tis now, indeed, Uncle, your're too positive.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: And you to Impertinent: Therefore I resolve to quit your House; you shan't keep your Revels under the Roof where I am.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I'd have you to know, Sir, my Lady keeps no Revels beneath her Quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, Mrs. Pert, or I shall display your Quality in its proper Colours.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I don't care, say your worst of me, and spare not; but for my Lady—my Lady's a Widdow, and Widdows are accountable to none for their Actions—Well, I shall have a Husband one of those days, and be a Widow too, I hope.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Not unlikely, for the Man will hang himself the next day, I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: And if any, Uncle, pretends to controul my Actions—

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: He'd loose his labour, I'm certain—

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I'd treat him—

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Don't provoke me, Houswife, don't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Be gone, and wait in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: The Insolence of a Servant, is a great Honour to the Lady, no doubt; but I shall find a way to humble you both.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: Lookee, Unkle, do what you can, I'm resolv'd to follow my own Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Which infallibly carries you to Noise, Nonsence, Foppery and Ruin; but no matter, you shall out of my Doors, I'll promise you, my House shall no longer bear the Scandalous Name of a Basset Table: Husbands shall no more have cause to date their Ruin from my Door, nor cry there, there my Wife Gam'd my Estate away—Nor Children Curse my Posterity, for their Parents knowing my House.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No more threatning, good Unkle, act as you please, but don't scold, or I shall be oblig'd to call Alpiew again.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Very well, very well, see what will come on't; the World will censure those that Game, and, in my Conscience, I believe not without Cause.
sp.l: For she whose Shame, no good Advice can wake,
When Money's wanting, will her Virtue Stake.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Advice! Ha, ha, ridiculous Advice. (Enter Lady Lucy) No sooner rid of one mischief, but another follows—I foresee this is to be a day of Mortification, Alpiew.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Uncle's gone, you may come in, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: Fye, Cousin, does it become you to Laugh at those that give you Council for your good?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For my good! Oh, mon cour? Now cannot I Divine what 'tis, that I do more than the rest of the World, to deserve this blame.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Nor I, for the Soul of me.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: Shou'd all the rest of the World follow your Ladyship's Example, the order of Nature would be inverted, and every good, design'd by Heaven, become a Curse, Health and Plenty no longer would be known among us.—You cross the purpose of the Day and Night, you Wake when you should Sleep, and make all who have any dependence on you, Wake while you Repose.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Bless me, may not any Person Sleep when they please?

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: No, there are certain Hours, that good Manners, Modesty and Health require your Care; for Example disorderly Hours are neither Healthful nor Modest—And 'tis not Civil to make Company wait Dinner for your Dressing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, does any body Dine before four a Clock in London? For my part I think it an Ill-bred Custom, to make my Appetite Pendulum to the Twelfth hour.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Besides, 'tis out of Fashion to Dine by Day light, and so I told Sir Richard yesterday, Madam.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: No doubt, but you did, Mrs. Alpiew; and then you entertain such a Train of People, Cousin, that my Lady Reveller is as noted as a publick Ordinary, where every Fool with Money finds a Welcome.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Would you have me shut my doors against my Friends—Now she is jealous of Sir James Courtly. (aside.) Besides, is it possible to pass the Evenings without Diversions.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: No certainly—

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: I think the Play-house, the much more innocent and commendable Diversion.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: To be seen there every Night, in my Opinion, is more destructive to the Reputation.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: Well, I had rather be noted every Night in the front Box, then, by my absence, once be suspected of Gaming; one ruins my Estate and Character, the other diverts my Temper, and improves my Mind. Then you have such a number of Lovers.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh Cupid, is it a Crime to have a number of Lovers? If it be, 'tis the pleasantest Crime in the World. A Crime that falls not every day, to every Womans Lot.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: I dare be positive every Woman does not wish it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Because wishes have no Effect, Cousin, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: Methinks my Lord Worthy's Assiduity might have banish'd the admiring Croud by this time.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Banish'd 'em? Oh, Mon cour! what pleasure is there in one Lover; 'tis like being seen always in one Suit of Cloaths; a Woman, with one Admirer, will ne'er be a Reigning Toast.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: I am sure those that Encourage more, will never have the Character of a Reigning Virtue.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I slight the malicious Censure of the Town, yet defy it to asperse my Verture; Nature has given me a Face, a Shape, a Mein, an Air for Dress, and Wit and Humour to subdue. And shall I lose my Conquest for a Name.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Nay, and among the unfashionable sort of People too, Madam; for Persons of Breeding and Quality will allow, that Gallantry and Virtue are not inseperable.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: But Coquetry and Reputation are, and there is no differerence in the Eye of the World, between having really committed the Fault, and lying under the Scandal; for, my own part, I would take as much Care to preserve my Fame, as you would your Virtue.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A little pains will serve you for that, Cousin; for I never once heard you nam'd—A Mortification would break my Heart, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: L. Lucy.
sp.p: 'Tis better never to be nam'd, than to be ill spoke of; but your Reflections shall not Disorder my Temper. I could wish, indeed, to convince you of your Error, because you share my Blood; but since I see the Vanity of the attempt, I shall desist.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: I humbly thank your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, here's my Lord Worthy, Sir James Courtly, and Ensign Lovely, coming down; will your Ladyship see them?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Now have I a strong Inclination to Engage Sir James, to discompose her Gravity; for if I have any Skill in Glances, she loves him—but then my Lord Worthy is so peevish since our late Quarrel, that I'm afraid to Engage the Knight in a Ducl; besides, my Absence, I know, will teize him more, therefore, upon Consideration, I'le retire. Cousin Lucy; Good Morrow. I'le leave you to better Company, there's a Person at hand may prevent your Six-a-Clock Prayers.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Ha! Sir James Courtly—I must own I think him agreeable—but am sorry she believes I do. I'le not be seen; for if what I scarce know my self be grown so visible to her, perhaps, he too may Discover it, and then I am lost.
sp.l: While in the Breast our Secrets close remain,
'Tis out of Fortunes power to give us Pain.

div1.stage: Enter Lord Worthy, Sir James, Ensign Lovel.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha! was not that Lady Lucy?

sp.speaker: Ensign.
sp.p: It was—ah, Sir James, I find your Heart is out of Order about that Lady, and my Lord Worthy languishes for Lady Reveller.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: And thou art sick for Valeria, Sir Richard's Daughter. A poor distresled Company of us.

sp.speaker: Ensign,
sp.p: 'Tis true, that little she-Philosopher has made me do Pennance more heartily than ever my sins did; I deserve her by meer Dint of Patience. I have stood whole hours to hear her Assert that Fire cannot Burn, nor Water Drown, nor Pain Afflict, and forty ridiculous Systems—and all her Experiments on Frogs, Fish—and Flies, ha, ha, ha, without the lcast Contradiction.

sp.speaker: Ensign.
sp.p: Contradiction, no, no, I allow'd all she said with undoubtedly, Madam,—I am of your mind, Madam, it must be so—natural Causes, &c.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, I think it is a supernatural cause which Enables thee to go thro' this Fatigue, if it were not to raise thy Fortune, I should think thee Mad to pursue her; but go on and prosper, nothing in my Power shall be wanting to assist you—My Lord Worthy—your Lordship is as Melancholy as a losing Gamester.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Faith, Gentlemen, I'm out of Humour, but I don't know at what.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Why then I can tell you, for the very same reason that made your Lordship stay here to be Spectator of the very Diversion you hate—Gaming—the same Cause makes you uneasy in all Company, my Lady Reveller.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Thou hast hit it, James, I confess I love her Person, but hate her Humours, and her way of Living; I have some reasons to believe I'm not indifferent to her, yet I despair of fixing her, her Vanity has got so much the Mistress of her Resolution; and yet her Passion for Gain furmounts her Pride, and lays her Reputation open to the World. Every Fool that has ready Money, shall dare to boast himself her very humble Servant; 'ds Death, when I could cut the Rascal's Throat.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: your Lordship is even with her one Way, for you are as testy as she's vain, and as fond of an opportunity to Quarrel with her, as she of a Gaming Acquaintance; my Opinion is, my Lord, she'll ne're be won your Way.
sp.l: To gain all Women there's a certain Rule,
If Wit should sail to please, then Act the Fool;
And where you find simplicity not take,
Throw off Disguises—and Profess the Rake;
Observe which Way their chiefest Humours run,
They're by their own lov'd, can't the surest Way undone.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Thou'rt of a happy temper, Sir James, I wish I could be so too; but since I can't add to your Diversion, I'll take my leave, good Morrow, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: This it is to have more Love than Reason about one; you and I Lovely will go on with Discretion, and yet I fear it's in Lady Lucy's Power to banish it.

sp.speaker: Ensign.
sp.p: I find Mrs. Sago, the Drugsters Wife's Interest, begins to shake, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: And I fear her Love for Play begins to shake her Husband's Baggs too—faith, I am weary of that Intreague, lest I should be suspected to have a hand in his Ruin.

sp.speaker: Ensign.
sp.p: She did not lose much to Night, I believe; preethy, Sir James, what kind of a temper'd Woman is she? Has she Wit?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: That she has—A large Portion, and as much Cunning, or she could never have manag'd the old Fellow so nicely; she has a vast Passion for my Lady Reveller, and endeavours to mimick her in every thing—Not a sute of Cloaths, or a Top-knot, that is not exactly the same with hers—then her Plots and Contrivances to supply these Expences, puts her continually upon the Rack; yet to give her her due, she has a fertile Brain that Way; but come, shall we go home and sleep two or three Hours, at Dinner I'll introduce you to Capt. Hearty, the Sea Officer, your Rival that is to be, he's just come to Town.

sp.speaker: Ensign.
sp.p: A powerful Rival, I fear, for Sir Richard resolves to Marry him to his Daughter; all my hopes lyes in her Arguments, and you know Philosophers are very positive—and if this Captain does but happen to Contradict one Whimsical Notion, the Poles will as soon join, as they Couple, and rather then yield, she would go to the Indies in search of Dampier's Ants.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Nay, she is no Woman if she Obeys.
sp.l: Women like Tides with Passions Ebb and Flow,
And like them too, their source no Man can know.
To watch their Motions, is the safest Guide,
Who hits their Humour, Sails with Wind and Tide.

div1.trailer: The End of the First ACT.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: GOod Morrow.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Good Morrow.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Good Morrow, good Morrow, is that all your business here; What means that Affected Look, as if you long'd to be examin'd what's the Matter.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.p: The Capricio's of Love, Madamoselle; the Capricio's of Love.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Why—are you in Love?

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.p: I—in Love! No, the Divel take me if ever I shall be infected with that Madness, 'tis enough for one in a Family to Fall under the whimsical Circumstances of that Distemper. My Lord has a sufficient Portion for both; here—here—here's a Letter for your Lady, I believe the Contents are not so full of Stars and Darts, and Flames, as they us'd to be.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: My Lady will not concern her self with your Lord, nor his Letters neither, I can assure you that.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.p: So much the better, I'le tell him what you say—Have you no more?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Tell him it is not my fault, I have done as much for his Service, as lay in my Power, till I put her in so great a Passion, 'tis impossible to Appease her.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Very good—my Lord is upon the Square, I promise ye, as much inraged as her Ladiship to the full. Well, Mrs. Alpiew, to the longest Day of his Life he fwears, never to forget Yesterday's Adventure, that's given him perfect, perfect Liberty.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I believe so—What was it, pray?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: I'll tell you; 'twas a matter of Consequence, I assure you, I've known Lovers part for a less Triffle by half.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: No Disgressions, but to the point, what was it?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: This—my Lord, was at the Fair with your Lady.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: What of that?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: In a Raffling-shop she saw a young Gentleman, which she said was very handsom—At the same time, my Lord, prais'd a young Lady; she redoubles her Commendations of the Beau—He enlarges on the Beauty of the Bell; their Discourse grew warm on the subject; they Pause; she begins again with the Perfections of the Gentleman; he ends with the same of the Lady; Thus they persu'd their Arguments, still finding such mighty Charms in their new Favourites, till they found one another so Ugly—so Ugly—that they parted with full Resolutions never to meet again.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, pleasant; well, if you have no more to tell me, adieu.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Stay a Moment, I see my Lord coming, I thought he'd follow me. Oh, Lovers Resolutions—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: So, have you seen my Lady Reveller? (To Buckle.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Ha! Mrs. Alpiew.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: There's your Lordship's Letter.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: An Answer! She has done me very much Honour.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: My Lord, I am commanded—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Hold a little, dear Mrs. Alpiew.
sp.stage: (All this while he is opening the Letter, thinking it from the Lady.)

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: My Lord, she would not—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Bequiet, I say—

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I am very sorry—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: But a moment—Ha, why, this is my own Letter.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord—what, she'd not receive it then?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: How durst you stay so long.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I beg your Lordship not to harbour an ill Opinion of me, I opposed her anger with my utmost Skill, prais'd all your Actions, all your Parts, but all in Vain.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Enough, Enough, Madam, she has taken the best method in the World—Well, then we are ne'er to meet again?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I know not that, my Lord—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I am over-joy'd at it, by my Life I am, she has only prevented me; I came a purpose to break with her—

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: (aside) Yes, so 'twas a sign by the pleasure you discover'd, in thinking she had writ to you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I suppose, she has entertain'd you with the Cause of this?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: No, my Lord, never mention'd a Syllable, only said, she had for ever done with you; and charg'd me, as I valued her favour, to receive no Message nor Letter, from you.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: May I become the very'st Wretch alive, and all the Ills immaginable fall upon my Head, if I speak to her more; nay, ever think of her but with Scorn—Where is she now?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: In her Dressing-room.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: There let her be, I am weary of her fantastick Humours, affected Airs, and unaccountable Passions.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: For half an Hour. (Aside)

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Do you know what she's a doing?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I believe, my Lord, trying on a Mantua; I left her with Mrs. Pleatwell, and that us'd to hold her a great while, for the Woman is saucily Familiar with all the Quality, and tells her all the Scandal.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And conveys Letters upon occasion; 'tis tack'd to their Profession—But, my Lady Reveller may do what she pleases, I am no more her Slave, upon my Word; I have broke my Chain—She has not been out then since she Rose?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Nay, if she has, or has not, 'tis the same thing to me; she may go the end of the World, if she will; I shan't take any pains to follow her—Whose Footman was that I met?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I know not, my Lord, we have so many come with How-dee's, I ne'er mind them.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: You are uneasy, Child, come, I'll not detain you, I have no curiosity, I protest I'm satisfied if she's so, I assure ye, let her despise me, let her hate me, 'tis all one, adieu. (Going.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: My Lord, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Mrs Alpiew, let me beg one favour of you, (turns back.) not to say I was here.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I'll do just as you please, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Do that then, and you'll oblige me,

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I will. (Is going, and comes back often.)

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Don't forget.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Your Lordship may depend upon me.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Hold, now I think on't—Pray tell her you did see me, do ye hear?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: With all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Tell her how indifferent she is to me in every respect.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I shan't fail.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Tell her every thing, just as I exprest it to you.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Adieu (going.)

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Now, I think on't, Mrs Alpiew, I have a great mind she shou'd know my Sentiments from my own Mouth.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Nay, my Lord, I can't promise you that.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Because she has expresly forbid your admittance.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I'd speak but one Word with her.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Impossible.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Pugh, prethee do, let me see her, (intreating Mrs Alpiew.)

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: So now, all this mighty rage ends in a begging Submission.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Only tell her I'm here.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Why should you desire me to meet her Anger, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Come, you shall oblige me once.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Oh, dear, my Lord, you have such a command over your Servant, I can refuse nothing.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Have you been at the Goldsmiths about the Bills, for I am fix'd on Travelling.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Your Lordship's so disturb'd, you have forgot you Countermanded me, and send me hither.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p:
Just as I told your Lordship, she fell in a most violent Passion, at the bare mention of your Name; tell him,
said she, in a heroick Strain, I'll never see him more, and command him to quit that Room, 'cause I'm coming to't.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Tyrant, curse on my Follies, she knows her Power; well, I hope, I may walk in the Gallery; I would speak with her Uncle.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: To be sure, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Learn, Mistress, learn, you may come to make me Mad in time, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Go Fool, follow your Lord.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, I'll swear, Alpiew, you have given me the Vapours for all Day.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Ah! Madam, if you had seen him, you must have had Compassion; I would not have such a Heart of Adamant for the World; poor Lord, sure you have the strangest Power over him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Silly—one often Fanices one has Power, when one has none at all; I'll tell the Alpiew, he vex'd me strangely before this grand Quarrel; I was at Picquet with my Lady Love-Witt four Nights ago, and bid him read me a new Copy of Verses, because, you know, he never Plays, and I did not well know what to do with him; he had scarce begun, when I being eager at a Pique, he rose up, and said, he believ'd I lov'd the Musick of my own Voice, crying Nine and Twenty, Threescore, better than the sweetest Poetry in the Universe, and abruptly left us.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: A great Crime, indeed, not to read when People are at a Game they are oblig'd to talk to all the while.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Crime, yes, indeed was it, for my Lady loves Poetry better than Play, and perhaps before the Poem had been done had lost her Money to me. But, I wonder, Alpiew, by what Art 'tis you engage me in this Discourse, why
shou'd I talk of a Man that's utterly my Aversiou—Have you heard from Mrs. Sago this Morning?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Certainly, Madam, she never sails; she has sent your Ladiship the finest Cargo made up of Chocolate, Tea, Montifiasco Wine, and 50 Rarities beside, with something to remember me, good Creature, that she never forgets. Well, indeed, Madam, she is the best natur'd Woman in the World; it grieves me to think what Sums she loses at Play.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh fye, she must, a Citizen's Wife is not to be endur'd amongst Quality; had she not Money, 'twere impossible to receive her—

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Nay, indeed, I must say that of you Women of Quality, if there is but Money enough, you stand not upon Birth or Reputation, in either Sex; if you did, so many Sharpers of Covent-Garden, and Mistresses of St. James's, would not be daily admitted.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Peace, Impertinence, you take strange Freedoms.
Why in such hast Cousin Valeria. [Stopping her.]

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh! dear Cousin, don't stop me, I shall lose the finest Infect for Desection, a huge Flesh Fly, which Mr. Lovely sent me just now, and opening the Box to try the Experiment away it flew.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am glad the poor Fly escap'd; will you never be weary of these Whimsies?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Whimsies! natural Peilosophy a Whimsy! Oh, the unlearn'd World.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ridiculous Learning?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Ridiculous, indeed, for Women; Philosophy Sutes our Sex, as Jack Boots would do.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Custom would bring them as much in Fashion as Furbeloes, and Practice would make us as Valiant as e're a Hero of them all; the Resolution is in the Mind,—Nothing can enslave that.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Stars! this Girl will be Mad, that's certain.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Mad! so Nero Banish'd Philosophers from Rome, and the first Discoverer of the Antipodes was Condemn'd for a Heretick.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: In my Conscience, Alpiew, this pritty Creature's spoil'd. Well, Cousin, might I Advise, you should bestow your Fortune in Founding a College for the Study of Philosophy, where none but Women should be admitted, and to Immortalize your Name, they should be call'd Valerians, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What you make a Jest of, Id'e Execute, were Fortune in my Power.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: All Men would not be Excluded, the handsom Ensign, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: In Love? Nay, there's no Philosophy against Love, Solon for that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pisha, no more of this Triffling Subject; Cousin, will you believe there's any thing without Gaul?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I am satisfy'd I have one, when I lose at Play, or see a Lady Addrest when I am by, and 'tis equal to me, whether the rest of the Creation have or not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Well, but I'le convince you then, I have dissected my Dove—and positively I think the Vulgar Notion true, for I could find none.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, Barbarous; kill'd your pritty Dove! [Starting.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Kill'd it! Why, what did you Imagine I bred it up for? Can Animals, Insects or Reptils, be put to a Nobler use, than to improve our Knowledge? Cousin, I'll give you this Jewel for your Italian Grey-hound.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What, to Cut to Pieces? Oh, horrid! he had need be a Soldier that ventures on you, for my part, I should Dream of nothing but Incision, Dissection and Amputation, and always fancy the Knife at my Throat.
Madam, here's Sir Richard, and a—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A— What, is it an Accident, a Substance, a Material Being, or, a Being of Reason?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I don't know what you call a Material Being; it is a Man.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: P'sha, a Man, that's nothing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: She'll prove by and by out of Discartes, that we are all Machines.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, do you see who observes you? My Lord walking in the Gallery, and every Minute gives a Peep.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Does he so? I'll fit him for Eves-dropping—

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Sir, I like the Relation you have given me of your Naval Expedition, your Discourse speaks you a Manfit for the Sea.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You had it without a flourish, Sir Richard, my Word is this, I hate the French, Love a handsome Woman, and a Bowl of Punch.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Very Blunt.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: This is my Daughter, Captain, a Girl of sober Education; she understands nothing of Gaming, Parks and Plays.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Alp.
sp.p: But wanting these Diversions, she has supply'd the Vacancy with greater Follies. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A Tite little Frigate, [Salutes her] Faith, I think, she looks like a freshman Sea-sick—but here's a Gallant Vessel—with all her Streamers out, Top and Top Gallant—with your leave, Madam, (Salutes her) who is that Lady, Sir Richard?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis a Niece of mine, Captain—tho' I am sorry she is so, she values nothing that does not spend their days at their Glass, and their Nights at Basset, such who ne'er did good to their Prince, nor Country, except their Taylor, Peruke-maker, and Persumer.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Fy, fy, Sir, believe him not, I have a Passion, an extream Passion, for a Hero—especially if he belongs to the Sea; methinks he has an Air so Fierce, so Piercing, his very Looks commands Respect from his own Sex, and all the Hearts of ours.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: The Divel—Now, rather than let another Female have a Man to her self, she'll make the first Advances. (aside.)

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, we are preferr'd by you fine Ladies sometimes before the sprucer Sparks—there's a Conveniency in't; a fair Wind, and we hale out, and leave you Liberty and Money, two things the most acceptable to a Wife in Nature.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh! ay, it is so pretty to have one's Husband gone Nine Months of the Twelve, and then to bring one home fine China, fine Lace, fine Muslin, and fine Indian Birds, and a thousand Curiosities.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: No, no, Nine is a little too long, six would do better for one of your Constitution, Mrs.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, Madam, what think you of a cruising Voyage towards the Cape of Matrimony, your Father designs me for the Pilot, if you agree to it, we'll hoist Sail immediately.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I agree to any thing dictated by good Sense, and comprehended within the Borders of Elocution, the converss I hold with your Sex, is only to improve and cultivate the Notions of my Mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: What the Devil is she going upon now? [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I presume you'r a Mariner, Sir—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I have the Honour to bear the Queen's Commission, Madam.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pray, speak properly, positively, Laconically and Naturally.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: So she has given him a Broadside already.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Laconically? Why, why, what is your Daughter? Sir Richard, ha

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p:
May I be reduc'd to Wooden-Shoes, if I can tell you, the Devil; had I liv'd near a College, the Haunts of some Pedaunt might have brought this Curse upon me; but to have got my Estate in the City, and to have a Daughter run Mad after Philosophy, I'll ne'er suffer it in
the rage I am in, I'll throw all the Books and Mathematical Instruments out of the Window.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I dare say, Uncle, you have shook hands with Philosophy—for I'm sure you have banish'd Patience, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: And you Discretion—By all my hatred for the French, they'll drive me Mad; Captain I'll expect you in the next Room, and you Mrs Laconick, with your Philosophy at your Tail.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Shan't I come too, Uncle, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: By Neptune, this is a kind of a whimsical Family; well, Madam, what was you going to say so positively and properly, and so forth?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I would have ask'd you, Sir, if ever you had the curiosity to inspect a Mermaid—Or if you are convinc'd there is a World in every Star—We, by our Telliscopes, find Seas, Groves and Plains, and all that; but what they are Peopled with, there's the Query.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let your next Contrivance be how to get thither, and then you'll know a World in every Star—Ha, ha, she's fitter for Moorfields than Matrimony, pray, Madam, are you always infected, full and change, with this Distemper?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How has my reason err'd, to hold converse with an irrational Being—Dear, dear Philosophy, what immense pleasures dwell in thee!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam, John, has got the Fish you sent him in search of.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Is it alive?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Your Servant, your Servant, I would not lose the Experiment for any thing, but the tour of the new World.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, is your Ladiship troubled with thefe Vagaries too; is the whole House possest?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not I, Captain, the speculative faculty is not my Talent; I am for the practick, can lissen all Day, to hear you talk of Fire, substantial Fire, Rear and Front, and Line of Battle—admire a Seaman, hate the French,—love a Bowl of Punch? Oh, nothing so agreeable as your Conversation, nothing so Jaunty as a Sea Captain.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: So, this engages him to Play,—If he has either Manners or Money. (aside.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, give me the Woman that can hold me tack in my own Dialect—She's Mad too, I suppose, but I'll humour her a little. (aside) Oh, Madam, not a fair Wind, nor a rich Prize, nor Conquest o're my Enemies, can please like you; accept my Heart without Capitulation—'Tis yours, a Prisoner at Discretion.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, you must there contend with me; the Victory is not so easy as you imagine.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh fye, my Lord, you won't fight for one you hate and despise? I may trust you with the Captain, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This must be her Lover—And he is Mad another way; this is the most unaccountable Family I ever met with. (aside) Lookye, Sir, what you mean by contending I know not; but I must tell you, I don't think any Woman I have seen since I came ashoar worth Fighting for. The Philosophical Gimcrack I don't value of a Cockle Shell—And am too well acquainted with the danger of Rocks and Quick-sands, to steer into t'others Harbour.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: He has discover'd her already; I, only I, am blind. (aside.)

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But, Sir, if you have a mind to a Breathing, here tread upon my Toe, or speak but one Word in favour of the French, or against the Courage of our Fleet, and my Sword will start of its self, to do its Master, and my Country, Justice.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: How ridiculous do I make my self—Pardon me, Sir, you are in the right. I confess I scarce knew what I did.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I thought so, poor Gentleman, I pitty him; this is the effect of Love on shoar—When do we hear of a Tarr in these Fits, longer then the first fresh Gale—Well, I'll into Sir Richard, Eat with him, Drink with him: but to Match into his Generation, I'd as soon Marry one of his Daughters Mermaids.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Was ever Man so stupid as my self? But I will rouse from this Lethargick Dream, and seek elsewhere what is deny'd at home, absence may restore my Liberty.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, did you see my Keecky.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Keecky, what's that?

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: My Wife, you must know, I call her Keecky, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Not I, indeed—

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Nay, pray my Lord, ben't angry, I only want her, to tell her what a Present of fine Wine is sent her just now; and ha, ha, ha, ha, what makes me Laugh—Is that, no Soul can tell from whence it comes.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Your Wife knows, no doubt.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: No more than my self, my Lord—We have often Wine and Sweet-meats; nay, whole pieces of Silk, and the duce take me, if she could devise from whence; nay, sometimes she has been for sending them back again, but I cry'd, whose a Fool then—

sp.speaker: Lord,
sp.p: I'm sure thou art one in perfection, and to me insupportable. [Going]

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: My Lord, I know your Lordship has the Priviledge of this House, pray do me the Kindness if you find my Wife to send her out to me.

I ne'er saw so much of this Lord's Humour before; he is very Surly Methinks—Adod there are some Lords of my Wives Acquaintance, as Civil and Familiar with me, as I am with my Journeyman—Oh! here she comes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh Puddy, see what my Lady Reveller has presented me withal.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Hey Keecky, why sure you Rise—as the saying is, for at Home there's Four Hampers of Wine sent ye.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: From whence, Dear Puddy?

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Nay, there's the Jest, neither you nor I know. I offer'd the Rogue that brought it a Guinea to tell from whence it came, and he Swore he durst not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: No, if he had I'd never have Employ'd him again. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: So I gave him Half a Crown, and let him go.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: It comes very Opportunely pray Puddy send a Couple of the Hampers to my Lady Revelleras a small Acknowledgement for the Rich Present she has made me.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: With all my Heart, my Jewel, my Precious.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Puddy, I am strangely oblig'd to Mrs. Alpiew, do, Puddy, do, Dear Puddy.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Will ye, then? Do, Dear Puddy, do, lend me a Guinea to give her, do. [Hanging upon him in a Wheedling Tone.]

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: P'shaw, you are always wanting Guineas, I'll send her Half a Pound of Tea, Keecky.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Tea—sha—she Drinks Ladies Tea; do, Dear Pudd, do; can you deny Keecky now?

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Well, well, there.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Mrs. Alpiew, will you please to lay the Silk by for me, till I send for it, and accept of That?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Your Servant Madam, I'll be careful of it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Thank ye, Borrow as much as you can on't, Dear Alpiew. [Aside to her.]

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: I warrant you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I must Raise a Summ for Basset against Night.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Preethy Keecky, what kind of Humour'd Man is Lord Worthy? I did but ask him if he saw thee, and I Thought he would snapp'd my Nose off.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh a meer Woman, full of Spleen and Vapours, he and I never agree.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Adod, I thought so—I guest'd he was none of thy Admirers—Ha, ha, ha, why there's my Lord Courtall, and my Lord Harncit, bow down to the Ground to me wherever they meet me.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, the Goldsmith has sent in the Plate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Very well, take it along with the Silk. [Aside to her.]

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Here's the Jeweller; Madam, with the Diamond Ring, but he don't seem willing to leave it without Money.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Humph? I have a sudden Thought, bid him stay, and bring me the Ring—Now for the Art of Wheedling.—

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: What are you Whispering about? Ha? Precious.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Mrs. Alpiew says, a Friend of her has a Diamond Ring to Sell, a great Penny-worthand I know you love a Bargain Puddy.

sp.stage: Enter Alpiew, gives her the Ring.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: P'shaw, I don't care for Rings; it may be a Bargain, and it may not; and I can't spare Money; I have Paid for a Lot this Morning; consider Trade must go forward, Lambkin.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: See how it Sparkles.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Nay, Puddy, if it be not Worth your Money I don't desire you to Buy it; but don't it become my Finger, Puddy? See now.—

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Ah! that Hand, that Hand it was which first got hold of my Heart; well what's the Price of it; Ha, I am ravish'd to see it upon Keecky's Finger.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: What did he say the Price was? [To Alpiew.]

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Two Hundred Guineas, Madam. [Aside to Mrs. Sago.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Threescore Pound, Dear Pudd, the Devils in't if he won't give that. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Threescore Pounds? Why 'tis Worth a Hundred Child, Richly—'tis Stole—'tis Stole.—

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Stole? I'd have you to know the Owner is my Relation, and has been as great a Merchant as any in London, but has had the Misfortune to have his Ships fall into the Hands of the French, or he'd not have parted with it at such a Rate; it Cost him Two Hundred Guineas.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I believe as much; indeed 'tis very fine.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: So it is Keecky, and that Dear little Finger shall have it to let me Bite it; a little Tiny bit.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! Dear Pudd, you Hurt me.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Here—I han't so much Money about me, but ther's a Bill, Lambkin—there now, you'll Buss poor Puddy now, won't you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Buss him—yes that I will agen, and agen, and agen. Dear Pudd.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: You'll go Home with Puddy now to Dinner, won't you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Yes—a—Dear Puddy, if you desire it—I will—but—a—

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: But I promis'd my Lady Reveller to Dine with her, Deary—do, let me Pudd—I'll Dine with you to Morrow-day.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Nay, I'm sure my Lady won't Eat a bit if she don't stay.

sp.speaker: Sago.
sp.p: Well, they are all so Fond of my Wife, by Keecky, show me the Little Finger agen—Oh! Dear Little Finger, by Keecky. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: By own Pudd—Here Alpiew give him his Ring agen, I have my End, tell him 'tis to Dear.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: But what will you say when Mr. Sago. Misses it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I'll say—that it was two big for my Finger, and I lost it; 'tis but a Crying-bout, and the good Man melts into Pity—
sp.l: I'th' Married State, this only Bliss we find,
An Easie Husband to our Wishes kind.
Iv'e Gain'd my Point, Replenish'd Purse once more,
Oh! cast me Fortune on the Winning Shore.
Now let me Gain what I have Lost before.

div1.head: ACT. III.
div1.stage: The Scene draws, and discovers Valeria with Books upon a Table, a Microscope, putting a Fish upon it, several Animals lying by.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: SHA! Thou fluttering Thing.—So now I've fix'd it.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Madam, here's Mr. Lovely; I have introduc'd him as One of my Lady's Visitors, and brought him down the Back-stairs.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I'm oblig'd to you, he comes opportunely.
Oh! Mr. Lovely, come, come here, look through this Glass, and see how the Blood Circulates in the Tale of this Fish.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Wonderful! but it Circulates prettier in this Fair Neck.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pshaw—be quiet—I'll show you a Curiosity, the greatest that ever Nature made— [opens a Box] in opening a Dog the other Day I found this Worm.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Prodigious! 'tis the Joint-Worm, which the Learned talk of so much.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Ay, the Lumbricus Latus, or Foescia, as Hippocrates calls it, or Vulgarly in English the Tape-Worm.—Thudaeus tells us of One of these Worms found in a Human Body 200 Foot long, without Head or Tail.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I wish they be not got into thy Brain. [Aside.]
Oh you Charm me with these Discoveries.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Here's another Sort of Worm call'd Lumbricus teres Intestinalis.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I think the First you show'd me the greatest Curiosity.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis very odd, really, that there should be every Inch a Joint, and every Joint a Mouth.—Oh the profound Secrets of Nature!

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: 'Tis strangely Surprizing.—But now let me be heard, for mine's the Voice of Nature too; methinks you neglect your self, the most Perfect Piece of all her Works.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why? What Fault do you find in me?

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: You have not Love enough; that Fire would Consume and Banish all Studies but its own; your Eyes wou'd Sparkle, and spread I know not what, of Lively and Touching, o'er the whole Face; this Hand, when Press'd by him you Love, would Tremble to your Heart.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why so it does,—have I not told you Twenty Times I Love you,—for I hate Disguise; your Temper being Adapted to mine, gave my Soul the First Impression;—you know my Father's Positive,—but do not believe he shall Force me to any Thing that does not Love Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: But that Sea Captain Valeria.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: If he was a Whale he might give you Pain, for I should long to Dissect him; but as he is a Man, you have no Reason to Fear him.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Consent then to Fly with me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What, and leave my Microscope, and all my Things, for my Father to break in Pleces?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh Heav'ns! Oh Heav'ns! he is coming up the Back-stairs. What-shall we do?

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Humph, ha, cann't you put me in that Closet there?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh no, I han't the Key.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I'll run down the Great Stairs, let who will see me. [Going.]

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh no, no, no, no, not for your Life;—here, here, here, get under this Tub.
sp.stage: Throws out some Fish in Hast, and Turns the Tub over him.
sp.p: Sir, I'm here.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: What, at your Whims—and Whirligigs, ye Baggage? I'll out at Window with them. [Throwing away the Things.]

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh Dear Father, save my Lumbricus Latus.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I'll Lamprey and Latum you; what's that I wonder? Ha? Where the Devil got you Names that your Father don't understand? Ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Oh my poor Worm! Now have you destroy'd a Thing, that, for ought I know, England cann't produce again.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: What is it good for? Answer me that?—What's this Tub here for? Ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What shall I do now?—it is, a 'tis a—Oh Dear Sir! Don't touch the Tub,—for there's a Bear's Young Cub that I have brought for Dissection,—but I dare not tonch it till the Keeper comes.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I'll Cub you, and Keeper you, with a Vengeance to you; is my Money laid out in Bears Cubs?—I'll drive out your Cub.—
sp.stage: Opens the Door, stands at a Distance off, and with his Cane, lifts up the Tub, Lovely rises.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Oh the Devil discover'd, your Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p:
Oh! your Servant Sir—What is this your Bear's Cub? Ha Mistress? His Taylor has lick'd him
nto Shape I find.—What did this Man do here? Ha Huswife?—I doubt you have been studying Natural Philosophy with a Vengeance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, he only brought me a strange Fish, and hearing your Voice I was afraid you should be Angry, and so that made me hide him.

sp.speaker: Sir. Rich.
sp.p: A Fish,—'tis the Flesh I fear; I'll have you Married to Night.—I believe this Fellow was the Beggarly Ensign, who never March'd farther than from Whitehall to the Tower, who wants your Portion to make him a Brigadier, without ever seeing a Battel—Huswife, ha—tho' your Philosophical Cant, with a Murrain to you—has put the Captain out of Conceit, I have a Husband still for you;—come along, come along, I'll send the Servants to clear this Room of your Bawbles,— (pulls her off) I will so.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But the Servants won't, Old Gentleman, that's my Comfort still.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'm glad they are gone, for the Duce take me if I cou'd hit the Way out.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha—Ensign! luckily met; I have been Labouring for you, and I hope done you a Piece of Service. Why, you look surpriz'd.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Surpriz'd! so wou'd you, Sir Harry, if you had been whelm'd under a Tub, without Room to Breath.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Under a Tub! Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Twas the only Place of Shelter.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p:
Come, come, I have a better Prospect, the Captain is a very Honest Fellow, and thinks if you can bear with the Girl, you deserve her Fortune; here's your
Part, [Gives a Paper] he'll give you your Cue, he stays at his Lodging for you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What's the Design?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: That will tell you; quick Dispatch.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well, Sir James, I know you have a Prolifick Brain, and will rely on your Contrivances, and if it succeeds the Captain shall have a Bowl of Punch large enough to set his Ship afloat.

div1.stage: Lady Reveller, Lady Lucy, Mrs. Sago, appear.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: The Tea-Table broke up already! I fear there has been but small Recruits of Scandal to Day.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Well, I'll swear I think the Captain's a Pleasant Fellow.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: That's because he made his Court to her. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Uh—I Nauseate those Amphibious Creatures.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Umph, she was not Address'd to.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: He seems neither to want Sense, Honour, nor True Courage, and methinks there is a Beauty in his Plain Delivery.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: There spoke Sincerity without Affectation.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: How shall we pass the Afternoon?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Aye, Ladies, how shall we?

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: You here! I thought you had Listed your self Volunteer under the Captain to Board some Prize, you whisper'd so often, and sneak'd out one after another.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Who would give one self the Pains to Cruise Abroad, when all one Values is at Home?

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: To whom is this Directed? Or will you Monopolize and Ingross us all?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: No,—tho' you would wake Desire in every Beholder, I resign you to my Worthy Friend.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: And the rest of the Company have no Pretence to you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: That's more than she knows. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Beauty, like yours, wou'd give all Mankind Pretence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: So, not a Word to me; are these his Vows? [In an uneasie Air.]

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: There's One upon the Teaze already. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Why, you are in Disorder, my Dear; you look as if you had lost a Trant-Leva: What have you said to her, Sir James?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I said, Madam? I hope I never say any Thing to offend the Ladies. The Devils in these Married Women, they cann't conceal their own Intriegues, though they Swear us to Secrecy. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: You mistake, Cousin, 'tis his saying nothing to her has put her upon the Fret.

sp.speaker: Lady. Revel.
sp.p: Ah, your Observations are always Malicious.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I despise them, Dear Lady Reveller, let's in to Picquet; I suppose Lady Lucy would be pleas'd with Sir James alone to finish her Remarks.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Nay, if you remove the Cause, the Discourse ceases.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: [Going up to her.] This you draw upon your self, you will discover it. [To her.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Yes, your Falshood.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Come my Dear, Sir James, will you make One at a Pool?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, I'm to be at White's in Half an Hour, anon at the Basset-Table. I'm Yours.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: No, no, he cann't leave her. [Going, still looking back.]

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: They play Gold, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: [Going up to Lady Lucy] Madam, were your Heart the Stake I'd Renounce all Engagements to win that, or retrieve my own.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: I must like the Counterstake very well er'e I play so high.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Sir James, hearkee, One Word with you.
sp.stage: Breaking from Lady Reveller's Hand, pulling Sir James by the Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I knew she could not stir; I'll remove your Constraint, but, with my wonted Freedom, will tell you plainly—your Husband's Shop wou'd better become you than Gaming and Gallants. Oh Shame to Virtue, that we shou'd Copy Men in their most Reigning Vices!
sp.l: Of Virtue's wholesome Rules unjustly we complain,
When Search of Pleasures gives us greater Pain.
How slightly we our Reputation Guard,
Which lost but once can never be Repair'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Farewel Sentences.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Madam— [Whispers her Lady.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: So then, you'd persuade me 'twas the Care of my Fame.

sp.speaker: Sir Harry.
sp.p: Nothing else I protest, my Dear little Rogue; I have as much Love as you, but I have more Conduct.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Well, you know how soon I forgive you your Faults.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Now to what Purpose have I Lied my self into her good Graces, when I would be glad to be rid of her? [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p:
Booted and Spurr'd say you? Pray send him
up, Sir James; I suppose Trusty Buckle is come with some Diverting Embassy from your Friend.

div1.stage: Enter Buckle in a Riding Dress.

sp.speaker: Mr. Buckle.
sp.p: Why in this Equipage?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Ah! Madam.—

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Out with it.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Farewel Friends, Parents, and my Country; thou Dear Play-house, and sweet Park, Farewel.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Farewel, why, whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: My Lord and I am going where they never knew Deceit.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: That Land is Invisible, Buckle.

sp.speaker: Lady Revet.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Were my Lord of my Mind your Ladiship should not have had so large a Theme for your Mirth. Your Servant Ladies.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Well, but what's your Business?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: My Lord charg'd me in his Name to take his Everlasting Leave of your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Why, where is he a going pray?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: In search of a Country where there is no Women.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh dear, why what have the Women done to him pray?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Done to him, Madam? He says they are Proud, Perfidious, Vain, Inconstant, Coquets in England.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! He'll find they are everywhere the same.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: And this is the Cause of his Whimsical Pilgrimage? Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: And this proceeds from your ill Usage, Madam; when he left your House,—he flung himself into his Coach with such a Force, that he broke all the Windows,—as they say,—for my Part I was not there;—when he came Home he beat all his Servants round to be Reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Was you there, Buckle?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: No, I thank my Stars, when I arriv'd the Expedition was over;—in Haste he Mounted his Chamber,—flung himself upon his Bed,—Bursting out into a Violent Passion,—Oh that ever I should suffer my self to be impos'd upon, said he, by this Coquetish Beauty!

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Meaning me, Buckle, Ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Stay till I have finish'd the Piece, Madam, and your Ladiship shall judge;—she's as Fickle as she's Fair,—she does not use more Art to Gain a Lover, said he, than to deceive him when he is fix'd.—Humph. [Learing at her.]

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Pleasant—and does he call this taking Leave?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: A Comical Adieu.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, I'm not come to the Tragical Part of it yet, starting from his Bed.—

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I thought it had been all Farce,—if there be any Thing Heroick in't I'll set my Face and look Grave.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: My Relation will require it, Madam, for I am ready to weep at the Repetition: Had you but seen how often he Travast the Room, [Acting it] heard how often he stamp'd, what distorted Faces he made, casting up his Eyes thus, Biting his Thumbs thus.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, you'll make an Admirable Actor,—shall I speak to the Patentees for you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: But pray how did this end?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: At last, Madam, quite spent with Rage, he sunk down upon his Elbow, and his Head fell upon his Arm.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: What, did he faint away?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Oh, no.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: He did not die?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: No, Madam, but he fell asleep.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh Brave Prince Prettiman.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: After Three Hours Nap he Wak'd—and calling hastily—my Dear Buckle, said he, let's to the End of the World; and try to sind a Place where the Sun Shines not here and there at one Time—for 'tis not fit that it should at once look upon Two Persons whose Sentiments are so Different—She no longer regards my Pain, Ungrateful, False, Inhumane, Barbarous Woman.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Foolish, Fond, Believing, Easie Man; there's my Answer—Come, shall we to Piquet, my Dear?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Madam, I han't half done—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! Pray my Dear Lady Reveller, let's have it out, 'tis very Diverting—

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: He call'd me in a feeble Voice; Buckle, said he, bring me my little Serutore—for I will write to Lady Reveller before I part from this Place, never to behold her more—what, don't you Cry, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Cry—No, no, go on, go on.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: 'Tis done, Madam—and there's the Letter.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: So, this Compleats the Narration. [Reads.]

Madam,
Since I cannot Live in a Place where there is a Possibility of seeing you without Admiring, I resolve to Fly; I am going for Flanders; since you are False I have no Business here—I need not describe the Pain I feel, you are but too well Acquainted with that—therefore I'll chuse Death rather than Return.—
Adieu.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Can any Man in the World write more Tenderly, Madam? Does he not say 'tis Impossible to Love you, and go for Flanders? And that he would rather hear of your Death then Return.—

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Excellent, Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: What, do you Laugh?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Who can forbear?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: I think you ought to Die with Grief; I warrant Heaven will punish you all. [Going.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Alp.
sp.p: But hearkee, Buckle, where are you going now?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: To tell my Lord in what Manner your Lady receiv'd his Letter; Farewel—now for Flanders.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Alp.
sp.p: A fair Wind, and a good Voyage to you.
sp.stage: [As he goes out enter Lord Worthy.]

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: My Lord, here? So now may I have my Head Broke for my long Harangue if it comes out.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh! Miraculous—my Lord, you have not finish'd your Campaign already, have you? Ha, ha, ha; or has the French made Peace at hearing of your Lordship's intended Bravery, and left you no Enemies to Combate?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: My worst of Foes are here—here, within my Breast; your Image, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh Dear, my Lord, no more of that Theme, for Buckle has given us a Surfeit on't already—even from your Breaking the Glasses of your Coach—to your falling fast Asleep. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: The Glasses of my Coach! What do you mean, Madam—Oh Hell! [Biting his Thumbs.]

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Ruined quite.—Madam, for Heavens sake what does your Ladiship Mean? I Li'd in every Syllable I told you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay, if your Lordship has a Mind to Act it over agen we will Oblige you for once—Alpiew set Chairs—come, Dear Sago, sit down—and let the Play begin—Buckle knows his Part, and upon Necessity cou'd Act yours too my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What has this Dog been doing? When he was only to deliver my Letter, to give her new Subject for her Mirth—Death, methinks I hate her,—Oh that I cou'd hold that Mind—what makes you in this Equipage? Ha! Sirrah? [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: My Lord, I, I, I, I,

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Peace Villain—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hey—this is Changing the Scene—

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Who the Devil would Rack his Brains for these People of Quality, who like no Body's Wit but their own?— [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: If the Beating were Invention before, thou hast it now in Reality; if Wars begin I'll Retire. They may agree better alone perhaps.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where did you learn this Rudeness, my Lord, to Strike your Servant before me?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: When you have depriv'd a Man of his Reason how can you blame his Conduct?

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Reason—Egad—there's not Three Drams of Reason between you both—as my Cheek can testifie. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The Affront was meant to me—nor will I endure these Passions—I thought I had forbid your Visits.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I thought I had Resolv'd against them to.

sp.speaker: Alpiew.
sp.p: But Resolutions are of small force of either side. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Grant me but this One Request and I'll remove this hated Object.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Upon Condition 'tis the last.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: It shall—I think it shall at least—Is there a Happy Man for whom I am Despised?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I thought 'twas some such ridiculous Question; I'm of the Low-Church, my Lord, consequently hate Confessors; ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: And Penance to I dare Swear. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And every thing but Play.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dare you, the Subject of my Power—you, that Petition Love, Arraign my Pleasures? Now I'm sixt—and will never see you more.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Now wou'd any Body Swear she's in Earnest.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
I cannot bear that Curse—see me at your Feet again, (Kneels) Oh! you have Tortur'd me enough,
take Pity now Dear Tyrant, and let my Suffering end.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I must not be Friends with him, for then I shall have him at my Elbow all Night, and spoil my Luck at the Basset-Table. [Aside.] Either Cringing or Correcting, always in Extreams—I am weary of this Fatigue.
sp.l: He that wou'd gain my Heart must Learn the Way
Not to Controul, but readily to Obey.
For he that once Pretends my Faults to see,
That Moment makes himself all Faults to me.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: There's the Inside of a Woman. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Gon—now Curses on me for a Fool—the worst of Fools—a Woman's Fool—
sp.l: Whose only Pleasure is to feed her Pride,
Fond of her Self, she cares for none beside.
So true Coquets on their numerous Charms Display,
And strive to Conquer on purpose to betray.

div1.head: ACT. III.
div1.stage: Enter Lord Worthy and Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Well, my Lord. I have left my Cards in the Hand of a Friend to hear what you have to say to me. Love I'm sure is the Text, therefore Divide and Subdivide as quick as you can.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Coud'st thou Infuse into me thy Temper, Sir James, I shou'd have thy Reason too; but I am Born to Love this Fickle, Faithless Fair—what have I not Essay'd to Race her from my Breast? But all in Vain; I must have her, or I must not Live.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Nay, if you are so far gone, my Lord, your Distemper requires an Able Physician—what think you of Loveley's bringing a File of Muscqueteers, and carry her away, Via & Armis?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: That Way might give her Person to my Arms, but where's the Heart?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: A Trifle in Competition with her Body.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: The Heart's the Gem that I prefer.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Say you so my Lord? I'll Engage Three Parts of Europe will make that Exchange with you; Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: That Maxim wou'd hold with me perhaps in all but her, there I must have both or none; therefore Instruct, me Friend, thou who negligent in Love, keeps always on the Level with the Fair—what Method shou'd I take to Sound her Soul's Design? For tho' her Carriage puts me on the Rack when I behold that Train of Fools about her, yet my Heart will plead in her Excuse, and Calm my Anger Spite of all Efforts.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Humph? I have a Plot, my Lord, if you'll comply with it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Nothing of Force.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Whate're it be you shall be Witness of it, 'twill either Quench your Flame, or Kindle hers. I only will appear the Guilty; but here's Company, I'll tell you all within.

div1.stage: Enter Captain and Lovely Drest like a Tar.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I'll expect you.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, Captain, How sits the Wind between you and your Mistress? Ha?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: North and by South, Faith; but here's one Sails full East, and without some unexpected Tornado, from the Old Man's Coast—he makes his Port I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I wish I were at Anchor once.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Why, thou art as arrant a Tar as if thou hadst made an East-India Voyage, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Ay, am I not, Sir James? But Egad I hope the Old Fellow understands nothing of Navigation; if he does I shall be at a loss for the Terms.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh! no matter for Terms—look big, and Bluster for your Country—describe the Vigo Business—publick News will furnish you with that, and I'll engage the Success.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, Ay, let me alone, I'll bear up with Sir Richard, and thou shalt Board his Pinnace with Consent ne'er fear.—ho, here he comes full Sail.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: I'm glad to see you; this is my Kinsman which I told you of, as soon as he Landed; I brought him to Kiss your Hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I Honour you, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I thank you Sir,—I'm not for Compliments; 'tis a Land Language I understand it not; Courage, Honesty, and Plain-dealing Truth, is the Learning of our Element; if you like that I am for ye. [Aside to the Captain.]

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: The Rogue does it to a Miracle.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: He's an improving Spark I find, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p:
Like it, Sir, why 'tis the only Thing I do like, hang Compliments, and Court-Breeding, it serves only to make Men a Prey to one another, to Encourage Cowardice, and Ruin Trade—No, Sir, give me the Man that dares meet Death and Dinner with the same Appetite—
one who rather than let in Popery, wou'd let out his Blood; to Maintain such Men I'd pay Double Custom; nay, all my Gain shou'd go for their Support. Gaptain lanch off a round Lie or Two. [Aside to the Ensign.]

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: The best Well-wisher to his Country of an Englishman I ever heard.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Oh, Sir Richard, I wish the Nation were all of your Mind, 'twou'd give the Soldiers and the Sailors Life.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And make us Fight with Heart and Hand; my Kinsman, I'll assure you, fits your Principle to a Hair; he hates the French so much he ne'er fails to give them a Broadside where'er he meets them; and has Brought in more Privateers this War than half the Captains in the Navy; he was the first Man that Boarded the French Fleet at Vigo—and in Gibraltar Business—the Gazettes will inform you of the Name of Captain Match.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Is this that Captain Match?

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: For want of better, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Sir, I shall be Proud of being known to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: And I of being Related to you, Sir,—I have a Daughter Young and Handsome, and I'll give her a Portion shall make thee an Admiral Boy; for a Soul like thine is fit only to Command a Navy—what say'st thou, art thou for a Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: So, 'tis done, ha, ha, ha. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A prosperous Gale I'faith.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I don't know, Sir Richard, mehap a Woman may not like me; I am Rough and Storm-like in my Temper, unacquainted with the Effeminacy of Courts; I was Born upon the Sea, and since I can remember never Liv'd Two Months on Shore; if I Marry my Wife must go Abroad, I promise you that.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p:
Abroad Man? Why she shall go to the Indies with the—Oh! such a Son-in-Law—how shall I be Blest in my Posterity? Now do I foresee the Greatness of
my Grand-Children; the Sons of this Man shall, in the Age to come, make France a Tributary Nation.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Once in an Engagement, Sir, as I was giving Orders to my Men, comes a Ball and took off a Fellow's Head, and struck it full in my Teeth; I wipp'd it up, clapp'd it into a Gun, and shot it at the Enemy again.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Without the least Concern?

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Concern, Sir,—ha, ha, ha, if it had been my own Head I would have done the like.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Prodigious Effect of Courage!—Captain I'll fetch my Girl, and be here again in an Instant:—What an Honour 'twill be to have such a Son!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, you outdo your Master.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, the Old Knight's Transported.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: I wish 'twas over, I am all in a Sweat; here he comes agrin.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I'll hear none of your Excuses,—Captain your Hand,—there take her,—and these Gentlemen shall be Witnesses, if they please, to this Paper, wherein I give her my whole Estate when I die, and Twenty Thousand Pounds down upon the Nail; I care not whether my Boy be worth a Groat,—get me but Grandsons and I'm Rich enough.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Generously said I'faith—much Good may do him with her.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
