sp.p: I'll do my Eedeavour, Father, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I wish you Joy, Captain, and you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
That's Impossible;—can I have Joy in a Species so very different from miy own? Oh my Dear Lovely!—We were only form'd one for another;—thy Dear Enquiring Soul is more to me—than all these useless Lumps of Animated Clay: Duty compels my Hand,—but my Heart is subject only to my Mind,—
the Strength of that they cannot Conquer;—no, with the Resolution of the Great Unparallell'd Epictetus,—I here protest my Will shall ne're assent to any but my Lovely.

sp.speaker: Sir Richard.
sp.p: Ay, you and your Will may Philosophize as long as you please,—Mistress,—but your Body shall be taught another Doctrine,—it shall so,—Your Mind,—and your Soul, quotha! Why, what a Pox has my Estate to do with them? Ha? 'Tis the Flesh Huswife, that must raise Heirs,—and Supporters of my Name;—and since I knew the getting of the Estate, 'tis fit I shou'd dispose of it,—and therefore no more Excuses, this is your Husband do you see,—take my Word for it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: The outward empty Form of Marriage take
But all beyond I keep for Lovely's Sake.
Thus on the Ground for ever fix my Eyes;
All Sights but Lovely shall their Balls despise.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Come, Captain,—my Chaplain is within, he shall do the Business this Minute: If I don't use the Authority of a Father, this Baggage will make me lose such a Son-in-law that the City's Wealth cann't purchase me his Fellow. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Thanks Dear Invention for this Timely Aid.
The Baits gon down, he's by himself betray'd.
Thus still where Arts both True and Honest fail,
Deceitful Wit and Policy prevail.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To Death, or any Thing,—'tis all alike to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p:
Get you in I say,—Hussey, get you in. In my Conscience my Niece has spoil'd her already; but I'll have her Married this Moment; Captain, you have bound
me ever to you by this Match, command me and my House for ever.—But shall I not have your Company, Gentlemen, to be Witnesses of this Knot, this joyful Knot?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes Faith, Sir Richard, I have too much Respect for my Kinsman to leave him—till I see him safe in Harbour; Ill wait on you presently.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I am engag'd in the next Room at Play, I beg your Pardon, Sir Richard, for an Hour; I'll bring the whole Company to Congratulate the Bride and Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Bride and Bridegroom? Congratulate me, Man: Methinks I already see my Race Recorded amongst the foremost Heroes of my Nation.—Boys, all Boys,—and all Soldiers.
sp.l: They shall the Pride of France and Spain pull down,
And add their Indies to our English Crown.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, never was Man so Bigotted before;—how will this end when he discovers the Cheat? Ha, ha, won't you make One with the Ladies, Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I don't care if I do venture a Piece or Two, I'll but dispatch a little Business and meet you at the Table, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, Lady Lucy! Is your Ladiship reconccil'd to Basset yet? Will you give me leave to lose this Purse to you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: I thank Fortune I neither wish, nor need it, Sir James; I presume the next Room is furnish'd with Avarice enough to serve you in that Affair, if it is a Burden to you; or Mrs. Sago's ill Luck may give you an Opportunity of returning some of the Obligations you lye under.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p:
Your Sex, Madam, extorts a Duty from ours,
and a well-bred Man can no more refuse his Money to a Lady, than his Sword to a Friend.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: That Superfluity of good Manners, Sir James, would do better Converted into Charity; this Town abounds with Objects—wou'd it not leave a more Glorious Fame behind you to be the Founder of some Pious Work; when all the Poor at mention of your Name shall Bless your Memory; than that Posterity shou'd say you Wasted your Estate on Cards and Women?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Humph, 'tis pity she were not a Man, she Preaches so Emphatically. [Aside.] Faith, Madam, you have a very good Notion, but something too Early—when I am Old, I may put your Principles in Practice, but Youth for Pleasure was design'd—

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: The truest Pleasure must consist in doing Good, which cannot be in Gaming.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Every thing is good in its Kind, Madam; Cards are harmless Bits of Paper, Dice insipid Bones—and Women made for Men.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Right, Sir James—but all these things may be perveted—Cards are harmless Bits of Paper in themselves, yet through them what Mischiefs have been Done? What Orphans Wrong'd? What Tradesmen Ruin'd? What Coach and Equipage dismist for them?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: But then, how many fine Coaches and Equipages have they set up, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Is it the more Honourable for that? How many Misses keep Coaches too? Which Arrogance in my Opinion only makes them more Eminently Scandalous—

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh! those are such, as have a Mind to be Damn'd in this State, Madam—but I hope your Ladiships don't Rank them amongst us Gamesters.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: They are Inseparable, Sir James; Madam's Grandeur must be Upheld—tho' the Baker and Butcher shut up Shop.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh! your Ladiship wrongs us middling Gentlemen there; to Ruin Tradesmen is the Qualities Prerogative only; and none beneath a Lord can pretend to do't with an Honourable Air, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Their Example sways the meaner Sort; I grieve to think that Fortune shou'd Exalt such Vain, such Vitious Souls—whilst Virtue's Cloath'd in Raggs.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ah! Faith, she'd make but a scurvy Figure at Court, Madam, the States-men and Politcians wou'd Suppress her quickly—but whilst she remains in your Breast she's safe—and makes us all in Love with that Fair Covering.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! Fie, Fi, Sir James, you cou'd not Love one that hates your chief Direction.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I shou'd Hate it too, Madam, on some Terms that I cou'd Name.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: What wou'd make that Conversion pray?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Your Heart.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: I cou'd pay that Price—but dare not Venture upon one so Wild— [Aside.] First let me see the Fruit e'er I take a Lease of the Garden, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh! Madam, the best Way is to Secure the Ground, and then you may Manure and Cultivate it as you please.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: That's a certain Trouble and uncertain Profit. and in this Affair; I prefer the Theory before the Practick But I detain you from the Table, Sir James—you are wanted to Tally—your Servant—

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Nay, if you leave me, Madam, the Devil will Tempt me—she's gone, and now cann't I shake off the Thought of Seven Wins, Eight Loses—for the Blood of me—and all this Grave Advice of hers is lost, Faith—tho' I do Love her above the rest of her Sex—she's an exact Model of what all Women ought to be,—and yet your Merry little Coquetish Tits are very Diverting—well, now for Basset; let me see what Money have I about—me. Humph! about a Hundred Gnineas—half of which will set the Ladies to Cheating—false Parolies in Abundance.
sp.l: Each Trifling Toy wou'd Tempt in Times of Old,
Now nothing Melts a Womans Heart like Gold.
Some Bargains Drive, other's more Nice then they,
Who'd have you think they Scorn to Kiss for Pay;
To Purchase them you must Lose Deep at Play.
With several Women, several Ways Prevail;
But Gold's a certain Way that cannot Fail.

div1.stage: The Scence Draws, and Discovers Lady Reveller, Mrs. Sago, and several Gentlemen and Ladies round a Table at Basset.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh! Sir James, are you come? We want you to Tally for us.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: What Luck, Ladies?

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I have only won a Sept & Leva.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: And I have lost a Trante & Leva—my Ill Fortune has not forsook me yet I see.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I go a Guinea upon that Card.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: You lose that Card.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I Mace Sir James's Card Double.

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: Seven wins, and Five loses; you have lost it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Agen?—sure never was Woman so Unlucky—

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: Knave wins, and Ten loses; you have Won, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Clean Cards here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Burn this Book, 'thas an unluckly Air. (Tears them.) Bring some more Books.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh! Captain—here set a Chair, come, Captain you, shall sit by me—now if we can but Strip this Tarr. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Withal my Heart, Madam—come, what do you Play Gold?—that's something High tho'—well a Guinea upon this Honest Knave of Clubs.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: You lose it for a Guinea more.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Done, Madam.

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: The Five Wins, and the Knave loses.

sp.speaker: Lady. Revel.
sp.p: You have lost it, Captain.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: The Knave wins, for Two Guineas more, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Done Sir James.

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: Six Wins—Knave Loses.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh! the Devil, I'm Fac't, I had rather have lost it all.

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: Nine wins, Queen loses—you have won,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I'll make a Paroli—I Mace as much more; your Card loses, Sir James, for Two Guineas, your's, Captain, loses for a Guineas more.

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: Four wins, Nine loses—you have Lost, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! I cou'd Tear my Flesh—as I Tear these Cards—Confusion—I can never win above a wretch'd Paroli; for if I push to Sept & Leva, tis gone.

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: Ace wins, Knave loses.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sink the Knave, I'll set no more on't.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Fac't agen—what's the meaning of this Ill-luck to Night? Bring me a Book of Hearts, I'll try if they are more Successful, that on the Queen; yours and your Cards loses.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Bring me a fresh Book; bring me another Book; bring me all Diamonds.
sp.stage: Looks upon them One by One, then throws them over her Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: That can never be lucky, the Name of Jewels don't become a Citizen's Wife. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Banker.
sp.p: King wins, the Tray loses.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: You have great Luck to Night, Mr. Sharper.

sp.speaker: Sharper.
sp.p: So I have Sir James—I have won Sonica every time.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: But if he has got the Nack of winning thus he shall sharp no more here, I promise him. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I Mace that.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Sir James, pray will you Telly.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs Sago.
sp.p: Pray give me the Cards, Sir.
sp.stage: [Takes 'em and shuffles 'em, and gives 'em to him again.]

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I set that.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I set Five Guineas upon this Card, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Done Madam,—Five wins,—Six loses.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I Set that.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Five don't go, and Seven loses.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I Mace double.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I Mace that.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Three wins, Six loses.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I Mace, I Mace double, and that—Oh ye malicious Stars!—again.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Eight wins Seven loses.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: So, this Trante & leva makes some Amends;—Adsbud I hate Cheating,—What's that false Cock made for now? Ha, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Rev.
sp.p: Nay, Mrs. Sago, if you begin to play foul.

sp.speaker: Mrs Sago.
sp.p: Rude Brute, to take Notice of the Slight of Hand in our Sex—I protest he wrongs me, Madam,—there's the Dernier, Stake,—and I'll set it all,—now Fortune Favour me, or this Moment is my last.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: There's the last of Fifty Pounds,—what's the Meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Now for my Plot, her Stock is low I perceive.
sp.stage: [Slips a Purse of Gold into the Furbeloes of Lady Reveller's Apron.]

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I never had such ill Luck,—I must fetch more Money: Ha; from whence comes this? This is the Genteelest Piece of Gallantry, the Action is Sir Harry's, I see by his Eyes.
sp.stage: Discovers a Purse in the Furbeloes of her Apron.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Nine wins, Six loses

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I am ruin'd and undone for ever; oh, oh, oh, to loose every Card, oh, oh, ho.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: So there's one Vessel sprung aleek, and I am almost ashoar—If I go on at this Rate, I shall make but a lame Voyage on't I doubt.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Duce wins, King loses.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I Mace again,—I Mace Double, I mace again;—now the Devil blow my Head off if ever I saw Cards run so; Dam 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Fie, Captain, this Concern among the Ladies is indecent.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Dam the Ladies,—mayn't I swear,—or tear my Cards if I please, I'm sure I have paid for them; pray count the Cards, I believe there's a false Tally.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: No, they are Right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Not to turn One Card! Oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Madam, if you play no longer pray don't disturb those that do.—Come, Courage, Captain,—Sir James's Gold was very lucky;—who cou'd endure these Men did they not lose their Money? [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Bring another Book here;—that upon Ten,—and I Mace that.—
sp.stage: [Puts down a Card, and turns another.]

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: King face't, Eight wins, Ten loses.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Fire and Gunpowder.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, what is the Captain vanish'd in his own Smoak?—Come, I Bett with you, Mr. Sharper; your Card loses.

div1.stage: Re-enter Captain, pulling in a Stranger, which he had fetch'd out of the Street.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sir, do you think it possible to lose a Trante & Leva a Quinse-leva,—and a Sept-et-leva,—and never turn once

sp.speaker: Stranger.
sp.p: No sure, 'tis almost Impossible.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Ounds you lie, I did Sir.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel. and all the Women.
sp.p: Ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p:
What the Devil, had I to do among these Land-Rats?—Zounds, to lose Forty Pounds for nothing, not so much as a Wench for it; Ladies, quotha,—a Man
had as good be acquainted with Pick-pockets.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, the Captain has frighted the Women out of their Wits,—now to keep my Promise with my Lord, tho' the Thing has but an ill Face, no Matter.
sp.l: They join together to Enslave us Men,
And why not we to Conquer them again.

div1.head: ACT. V.
div1.stage: Enter Sir James on one side, and Lady Reveller on the other.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: SIR James, what have you done with the Rude Porpois?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: He is gone to your Uncle's Apartment, Madam, I suppose.—I was in Pain till I knew how your Ladiship did after your Fright.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Really, Sir James, the Fellow has put me into the Spleen by his ill Manners. Oh my Stars! That there should be such an unpolished Piece of Humane Race, to be in that Disorder for losing his Money to us Women.—I was apprehensiev he would have beat me, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, ha, your Ladiship must impute his ill Breeding to the Want of Conversation with your Sex; but he is a Man of Honour with his own, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I hate out of fashion'd Honour.—But where's the Company, Sir James? Shan't we play again?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: All disperss'd, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Come, you and I'll go to Picquet then.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh I'm tir'd with Cards, Madam, cann't you think of some other Diversion to pass a chearful Hour?—I cou'd tell you One if you'd give me leave.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Of your own Invention? Then it must be a pleasant One.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh the pleasantest one in the World.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: What is it I pray?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Love, Love, my Dear Charmer.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh Cupid! How came that in your Head?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis in my Heart, and except you pity me the Wound is Mortal.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, is Sir James got into my Lord Worthy's Class?—You that could tell me I should not have so large a Theme for my Diversion, were you in his Place, ha, ha, ha; what, and is the Gay, the Airy, the Witty, Inconstant, Sir James overtaken? Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Very true, Madam,—you see there is no jesting with Fire.—Will you be kind?

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Kind? What a dismal Sound was there?—I'm afraid your Feaver's high, Sir James, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: If you think so, Madam, 'tis time to apply cooling Medicines.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Ha, what Insolence is this? The Door lock'd! What do you mean Sir James?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh 'tis something indecent to Name it, Madam, but I intend to show you.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Unhand me, Villain, or I'll cry out.—

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Do, and make your self the Jest of Servants, expose your Reputation to their vile Tongues,—which if you please shall remain safe within my Breast; but if with your own Noise you Blast it, here I bid Defiance to all Honour and Secrecy,—and the First Man that enters dies.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: What shall I do? Instruct me Heaven—Monster, is this your Friendship to my Lord? And can you wrong the Woman he Adores.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ay, but the Woman does not care a Souse for him; and therefore he has no Right above me; I love you as much, and will possess.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh! hold—Kill me rather than destroy my Honour—what Devil has Debauch'd your Temper? Or how has my Carriage drawn this Curse upon me? What have I done to give you cause to think you ever shou'd succeed this hated Way.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p:
Why this Question, Madam? Can a Lady
that loves Play so passionately as you do—that takes as much Pains to draw Men in to lose their Money, as a Town Miss to their Destruction—that Caresses all Sorts of People for your Interest, that divides your time between your Toylet and the Basset-Table; (can you, I say, boast of Innate Virtue?—Fie, fie, I am sure you must have guess'd for what I Play'd so Deep—we never part with our Money without Design—or writing Fool upon our Foreheads;—therefore no more of this Resistance, except you would have more Money.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Oh! horrid.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: There was Fifty Guineas in that Purse, Madam—here's Fifty more; Money shall be no Dispute.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: [Strikes it Down.] Perish your Money with your self—you Villain—there, there; take your boasted Favours, which I resolv'd before to have Repaid in Specie; Basest of Men I'll have your Life for this Affront—what ho, within there.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Hush—Faith, you'll Raise the House. [Lays hold on her.] And 'tis in Vain—you are mine; nor will I quit this Room till I'm Possest.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Raise the House, I'll raise the World in my Defence, help, Murther, Murther,—a Rape, a Rape—

div1.stage: Enter Lord Worthy from another Room with his Sword Drawn.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Ha! Villain, unhand the Lady—or this Moment is thy last.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Villain, Back my Lord—follow me.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: By the Bright Sun that Shines you shall not go—no, you have sav'd my Virtue, and I will preserve your Life—let the vile Wretch be punish'd by viler Hands—yours shall not be Prophan'd with Blood so Base, if I have any Power—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
Shall the Traytor Live?—Tho' your Barbarous Usage does not Merit this from me, yet in Consideration
that I Lov'd you once—I will Chastise his Insolence.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Once—Oh! say not once; do you not Love me still? Oh! how pure your Soul appears to me above that Detested Wretch.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: [Peeping.] It takes as I cou'd Wish—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Yet how have I been slighted, every Fop preferr'd to me?—Now you Discover what Inconveniency your Gaming has brought you into—this from me wou'd have been unpardonable Advice—now you have prov'd it at your own Expence.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: I have, and hate my self for all my Folly—Oh! forgive me—and if still you think me Worthy of your Heart—I here Return you Mine—and will this Hour Sign it with my Hand.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: How I Applaud my self for this Contrivance.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Oh! the Transporting Joy, it is the only Happiness I Covet here.
sp.l: Haste then my Charmer, haste the long'd-for Bliss.
The only Happy Minutes of my Life is this.
sp.p: Sir James. Ha, ha, ha, ha, how am I Censur'd now for doing this Lady a iece of Service, in forcing that upon her, which only her Vanity and Pride Restrain'd.
sp.l: So Blushing Maids refuse the Courtd Joy,
Tho' wishing Eys—and pressing Hands Comply,
Till by some Stratagem the Lover Gains,
What she deny'd to all his Amorous Pains.

div1.stage: As Sir James is going off, enter Lady Lucy meeting him.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Ha, Lady Lucy!—Having Succeeded for my Friend, who knows but this may be my Lucky Minute too?—Madam, you come Opportunely to hear.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Stand off Basest of Men, I have heard too much; coud'st thou Chuse no House but this to Act thy Villanies in? And cou'd'st thou fairly offer Vows to me, when thy Heart, Poison'd with vicious Thoughts, harbour'd this Designs against my Family?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p:
Very fine, Faith, this is like to be my Lucky
Minute with a Witness; but Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Offer not at Excuses, 'tis height of Impudence to look me in the Face.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Egad she Loves me—Oh! Happy Rogue—this Concern can proceed from nothing else. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: My Heart till now unus'd to Passion swells with this Affront, wou'd Reproach thee—wou'd Reproach my self, for having Harbour'd one favourable Thought of thee.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Why did you, Madam?—Egad I owe more to her Anger than ever I did to her Morals.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Ha! What have I said?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: The only kind Word you ever utter'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Yes, Imposture, know to thy Confusion that I did love the, and fancy'd I Discover'd some Seeds of Virtue amongst that Heap of Wickedness; but this last Action has betray'd the Fond Mistake, and show'd thou art all o'er Feign'd.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Give me leave, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Think not this Confession meant to advance thy Impious Love, but hear my Final Resolution.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Egad I must hear it—I find for there's no stopping her.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: From this Moment I'll never—

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: (Clapping his and before Her Mouth.) Nay, nay, nay, after Sentence no Criminal is allow'd to Plead; therefore I will be hear'd—not Guilty, not Guilty. Madam, by—if I don't prove that this is all a Stratagem, Contriv'd, Study'd, Design'd, Prosecuted, and put in Execution, to reclaim your Cousin, and give my Lord Possession—may you Finish your Curse, and I Doom'd to Everlasting Absence—Egad I'm out of Breath—

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: Oh! Cond'st thou prove this?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I can, if by the Proof you'll make me Happy; my Lord shall Convince you.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: To him I will refer it, on this Truth your Hopes Depend.
sp.l: In Vain we strive our Passions to Conceal,
Our very Passions does our Loves Reveal;
When once the Heart, yields to the Tyrants Sway,
The Eyes or Tongue will soon the Flame Betray.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: I was never out at a Critical Minute in my Life.

div1.stage: Enter Mr. Sago and Two Bailiffs meeting Alpiew.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Hearkee, Mistress, is my Wife here?

sp.speaker: Alp.
sp.p: Truly I shant give my self the Trouble of seeking her for him; now she has lost all her Money—your Wife is a very Indiscreet Person, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: I'm afraid I shall find it so to my Cost.

sp.speaker: Bailiffs.
sp.p: Come, come, Sir, we cann't wait all Day—the Actions are a Thousand Pound—you shall have time to send for Bail, and what Friends you Please.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: A Thousand Pound? [Enter Mrs. Sago.] Oh! Lambkin have you Spent me a Thousand Pound.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Who, I Pudd? Oh! undone for Ever—

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Pud me no Pud,—do you Owe Mr. Tabby the Mercer Two Hundred Pounds? Ha.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: I, I, I, don't know the Sum Dear Pudd—but, but, but I do Owe him something; but I believe he made me Pay too Dear.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! thou Wolfkin instead of Lambkin—for thou hast Devour'd my Substance; and dost thou Owe Mr. Dollor the Goldsmith Three Hundred Pound? Dost thou? Ha, speak Tygress.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Sure it cann't be quite Three Hundred Pound. [Sobbing]

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Thou Island Crocodile thou—and dost thou Owe Ratsbane the Vintner a Hundred Pound? And were those Hampers of Wine which I receiv'd so Joyfully sent by thy self, to thy self? Ha.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Puddy—I, I, I, beg your Pardon. [Sobbing.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: And why didst not thou tell me of them? Thou Rattle-Snake?—for they say they have sent a Hundred times for their Money—else I had not been Arrested in my Shop.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Be, be, be, because I, I, I was afraid, Dear Puddy. [Crying.]

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: But wer't not thou afraid to Ruin me tho, Dear Pudd. Ah! I need ask the, no more Questions, thou Serpent in Petticoats; did I Doat upon thee for this? Here's a Bill from Calico the Linnen-Draper, another from Setwell the Jeweller—from Coupler a Mantua-Maker, and Pimpwell the Milliner; a Tribe of Locusts enough to undo a Lord Mayor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I hope not, truly, Dear, Dearey, I'm sure that's all.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: All with a Pox—no Mrs. Jezebel, that's. not all; there's Two Hundred Pound Due to my self for Tea, Coffee and Chocolet, which my Journey-man has Confess'd fince your Roguery came out—that you have Imbezell'd, Huswife, you have; so, this comes of your keeping Quality Company—e'en let them keep you now, for I have done with you, you shall come no more within my Doors I promise you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! Kill me rather; I never did it with Design to part with you, indeed Puddy. [Sobbing.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: No, no, I believe not whilst I was Worth a Groat. Oh!

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: How! Mrs. Sago in Tears, and my honest Friend in Ruffins Hands; the meaning of this.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Oh! Sir James—my Hypocritical Wife is as much a Wife as any Wife in the City—I'm Arrested here in an Action of a Thousand Pound, that she has taken up Goods for, and Gam'd away; get out of my sight, get out of my sight, I say.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Indeed and indeed. [Sobbing.] Dear Puddy but I cannot—no, here will I Hang forever on this Neck.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Help, Murder, Murder, why, why, what will you Collar me?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Right Woman, I must try to make up this Breach—Oh! Mr. Sago, you are unkind—'tis pure Love that thus Transports your Wife, and not such Base Designs as you Complain of.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and she run me in Debt out of pure Love to no doubt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: So it was Pudd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: What was it? (Ha Mistress) out of love to me that you have undone me? Thou, thou, thou, I don't know what to call thee bad enough.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: You won't hear your Keckey out, Dear Pudd, it was out of Love for Play,—but for Lo, Lo, Love to you, Dear Pudd; if you'll forgive me I'll ne'er play again. (Crying and Sobbing all the while.)

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Nay, now, Sir, you must forgive her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: What, forgive her that would send me to Jayl?

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: No, no, there's no Danger of that, I'll Bail you, Mr. Sago, and try to Compound those Debts.—You know me Officers.

sp.speaker: Officers.
sp.p: Very well, Sir James, your Worship's Word is sufficient.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: There's your Fees, then leave here your Prisoner, I'll see him forth coming.

sp.speaker: Officers.
sp.p: With all our Hearts; your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Ah thou wicked Woman, how I have doated on those Eyes! How often have I kneel'd to kiss that Hand! Ha, is not this true, Keckey?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Yes, Deary, I, I, I, I do confess it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Did ever I refuse to grant wbatever thou ask'd me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: No, never, Pudd.—

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago,
sp.p: Might'st thou not have eaten Gold, as the Saying is? Ha?—Oh Keecky, Keecky!

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Leave Crying, and wheedle him, Madam, wheedle him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I do confess it, and cann't you forgive your Keckey then that you have been so Tender of, that you so often confest your Heart has jump'd up to your Motuh when you have heard my Beauty prais'd.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p:
So it has I profess, Sir James,—I begin to melt,—I do; I am a good-natur'd Fool, that's the Truth on't: But if I should sorgive you, what would you
do to make me Amends? For that Fair Face, if I turn you out of Doors, will quickly be a cheaper Drug than any in my Shop.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: And not maintain her half so well;—promise largely, Madam. [To Mrs. Sago.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: I'll Love you for ever, Deary.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: But you'll Jigg to Covent-Garden again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: No, indeed I won't come within the Air on't, but take up with City Acquaintance, rail at the Court, and go Twice a Week with Mrs. Outside to Pin-makers-hall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: That would rejoice my Heart.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: See, if the good Man is not ready to weep; your last Promise has conquer'd.—Come, come, Buss and be Friends, and end the Matter.—I'm glad the Quarrel is made up, or I had had her upon my Hands. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Pudd, don't you hear Sir James, Pudd?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: I can hold no longer,—yes, I do hear him,—come then to the Arms of thy n'own Pudd.

sp.speaker: Sir Jam.
sp.p: Now all's well; and for your Comfort Lady Reveller is by this Time married to my Lord Worthy, and there will be no more Gaming I assure you in that House.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: Joys upon Joys. Now if these Debts were but Accommodated, I should be happier than ever; I should indeed Kickky.

sp.speaker: Sir Jam.
sp.p: Leave that to me, Mr. Sago, I have won Part of your Wife's Money, and will that Way restore it you.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: I thank you, good Sir James, I believe you are the First Gamester that ever Refunded.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Generously done,—Fortune has brought me. off this Time, and I'll never trust her more.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: But see the Bride and Bridegroom.

div1.stage: Enter Lord Worthy and Lady Reveller, Lady Lucy, Buckle, Alpiew.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: This Match which I have now been Witness to, is what I long have wish'd, your Course of Life must of Necessity be chang'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: Ha, Sir James here!—Oh if you love me, my Lord let us avoid that Brute, you must not meet him.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Oh, there's no Danger, Madam.—My Lord, I wish you Joy with all my Heart; we only quarrell'd to make you Friends, Madam, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: What, am I trick'd into a Marriage then?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Not against your Will, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: No, I forgive you; tho' had I been aware of it, it should have cost you a little more Pains.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I wish I could return thy Plot, and make this Lady thine, Sir James.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: Then I should be paid with Interest, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lady Lucy.
sp.p: My Fault is Consideration you know, I must think a little longer on't.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: And my whole Study shall be to improve those Thoughts to my own Advantage.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: I wish your Ladiship Joy, and hope I shall keep my Kickey to my self now.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With all my Heart Mr. Sago, she has had ill Luck of late, which I am sorry for.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: My Lord Worthy will confine your Ladiship from Play as well as I, and my Injunction will be more casie when I have your Example.

sp.speaker: Buclke.
sp.p: Nay 'tis Time to throw up the Cards when the Games out.

div1.stage: Enter Sir Richard, Captain Hearty, Lovely and Valeria.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, Sir James, the Danger's over, we have doubled the Cape, and my Kinsman is Sailing directly to the Port.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: A Boon Voyage.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: 'Tis done, and my Heart is at Ease.—Did you ever see such a perverse Baggage, look in his Face I say, and thank your Stars, for their best influences gave yon this Husband.

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Will not Valeria look upon me? She us'd to be more Kind when we have sish'd for Eals in Vinegar.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My Lovely, is it thee? And has natural Sympathy forborn to inform my Sense thus long?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: How! how! This Lovely? What does it prove the Ensign I have so carefully avoided!

sp.speaker: Lovely.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, the same; I hope you may be brought to like a Land Soldier as well as a Seaman.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: And, Captain, have you done this?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, Faith, she was too whimsical for our Element; her hard Words might have Conjur'd up a Storm for ought I know—so I have set her ashore.

sp.speaker: Lady Revel.
sp.p: What, my Uncle deceiv'd with his Stock of Wisdom? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: Here's such a Coupling, Mrs. Alpiew, han't you a Month's Mind?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Alp.
sp.p: Not to you I assure you.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: I was but in Jest, Child, say nay when you're ask'd.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: The principal Part of this Plot was mine, Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Wou'd 'twas in my Power to hang you for't. [Aside.

sp.speaker: Sir James.
sp.p: And I have no Reason to doubt you should repent it, he is a Gentleman, tho' a younger Brother, he loves your Daughter, and she him, which has the best Face of Happiness in a married State; you like a Man of Honour, and he has as much as any one, that I assure you, Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Well, since what's past is past Recal I had as good be satisfied as not, therefore take her, and bless ye together.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: So now each Man's Wish is Crown'd, but mine with double Joy.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well said, Sir Richard, let's have a Bowl of Punch, and Drink to the Bridegroom's good Voyage to Night,—steady, steady, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sago.
sp.p: I'll take a Glass with you Captain,—I reckon my self a Bridegroom too.

sp.speaker: Buckle.
sp.p: I doubt Kickey won't find him such. [Aside.]

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sago.
sp.p: Well,—poor Keckky's bound to good Behaviour, or she had lost quite her Puddy's Favour.
sp.l: Shall I for this repine at Fortune?—No.
I'm glad at Heart that I'm forgiven so.
Some Neighbours Wives have but too lately shown,
When Spouse had left 'em all their Friends were flown.
Then all you Wives that wou'd avoid my Fate.
Remain contented with your present State
